gulpfile.js
¶

This file is used by the gulp module in order to perform build-related tasks.

Note that with gulp, each subtask is run asynchronously. This means they will run at the same time, thus saving time. There are additional hoops to jump though to make them synchronous.

See Gulp for more details.

 
10
¶

require the gulp module. Pretty important of this file! :)

 
12  
13  var gulp = require('gulp');
14  
15  
16
¶

Here is a plain JS object to hold the file paths in one place. This is done to make things a bit easier to manage if we change them later.

 
16  
17  var paths = {
18    gulpfile: 'gulpfile.js',
19    readme: 'README.md',
20    markup: 'src/**/*.html',
21    scriptsRoot: 'src/js/',
22    scripts: 'src/js/**/*.js',
23    assets: ['src/assets/*.png', 'src/assets/*.jpg','src/assets/*.json'],
24    css: 'src/css/*.css',
25    dist: 'dist',
26    docsOutput: 'dist/docs',
27    docsExclude: 'node_modules*,dist*',
28    mainjs: './src/js/main.js',
29    bundlejs: 'bundle.js'
30  };
31  
32  
33  
34

¶ build

This is the main task to build the project. Each build step is separted into a subtask to make things a bit easier to follow.

 
38  
39  gulp.task('build', ['lint-js', 'build-js', 'build-markup', 'build-assets', 'build-css', 'build-docs']);
40  
41  
42

¶ lint-js

A subtask called by the build task to "lint" all JavaScript files. If any files have linting issues (bad syntax, poor formatting, etc), they will show up in the console. The rules are controlled by the .jshintrc file. See the jshint.com site for more details.

 
46  
47  gulp.task('lint-js', function () {
48    var jshint = require('gulp-jshint');
49    var stylish = require('jshint-stylish');
50  
51    gulp.src(paths.scripts)
52      .pipe(jshint())
53      .pipe(jshint.reporter(stylish));
54  });
55  
56  
57

¶ build-js

This subtask will prepare all JS files for output. This is done by running all files through browserify. This will prepare the files to be used by the front-end and concatenate them into a single bundle.js file, which is the file included on index.html

Note that uglify step could be done here as well.

 
65  
66  gulp.task('build-js', function () {
67    var browserify = require('browserify');
68    var source = require('vinyl-source-stream');
69  
70
¶

uglify steps are commented out for now...

var streamify = require('gulp-streamify');
var uglify = require('gulp-uglify');

73  
74  
75    var bundleStream = browserify(paths.mainjs).bundle();
76  
77    bundleStream
78      .pipe(source(paths.bundlejs))
79  
80
¶ 
.pipe(streamify(uglify()))

81  
82    .pipe(gulp.dest(paths.dist + '/js'));
83  });

¶ build-markup

Simple task to copy the index.html file into the dist directory.

 
90  
91  gulp.task('build-markup', function () {
92    return gulp.src(paths.markup)
93      .pipe(gulp.dest(paths.dist));
94  });
95  
96  
97  
98

¶ build-assets

Another build subtask that will take all the images from the assets directory and run them through imagemin to compress down the images. These minified assets are dropped into the dist directory.

 
103  
104  gulp.task('build-assets', function () {
105    var imagemin = require('gulp-imagemin');
106    return gulp.src(paths.assets)
107      .pipe(imagemin())
108      .pipe(gulp.dest(paths.dist + '/assets'));
109  });
110  
111  
112  
113

¶ build-css

A simple task to copy css files directly over to the dist directory. Its called as a subtask to the build task. This task could be modified to do some fancy-pantsy css related things if thats your thing.

 
117  
118  gulp.task('build-css', function () {
119    return gulp.src(paths.css)
120      .pipe(gulp.dest(paths.dist + '/css'));
121  });
122  
123  
124

¶ build-docs

This task will generate the HTML documentation web pages using docker.js.

All documentation is extracted from comments directly in each JS file.

To reduce the time it takes to build, it will only rebuild the files that changed each time its run. To force all files to be rebuild, run gulp clean before this task.

 
134  
135  gulp.task('build-docs', function () {
136    var Docker = require('docker');
137  
138    var d = new Docker({
139      inDir: '.',
140      outDir: paths.docsOutput,
141      colourScheme: 'monokai',
142      ignoreHidden: 'true',
143      exclude: paths.docsExclude,
144      lineNums: true,
145      extras: ['fileSearch', 'goToLine'],
146      onlyUpdated: true
147    });
148  
149    return d.doc(['./']);
150  
151  });
152  
153  
154  
155

¶ watch

This task is used for development. Running gulp watch does the following:

trigger a fresh build of the whole project start up a web server at http://localhost:3002 that serves the built files. begin "watching" the soruce files. Changing a file triggers a rebuild of the project This also sends a message to the browser via livereload to refresh the page automatically.

This is a powerful little task that should help make it easy to test code quickly without having to kick off builds all the time. However, if a file is saved with a syntax error, it will kill the task. Just restart the task to continue.

This task will watch everything except dist and node_modules for documentation updates.

 
169  
170  gulp.task('watch', ['build', 'trigger-reload', 'build-markup-with-livereload', 'static-server'], function () {
171  
172    gulp.watch(paths.scripts, ['lint-js', 'build-js']);
173    gulp.watch(paths.markup, ['build-markup-with-livereload']);
174    gulp.watch(paths.assets, ['build-assets']);
175    gulp.watch(paths.css, ['build-css']);
176  
177    gulp.watch([paths.markup, paths.scripts, paths.readme, paths.gulpfile], ['build-docs']);
178  });
179  
180  
181

¶ static-server

This task will start a new connect web server with the root pointed at the dist directory. This is used by the watch task, but it can also be called directly.

By default the port used is http://localhost:3002, however you can override this by setting the environmental variable "PORT" before running gulp.

 
189  
190  gulp.task('static-server', function (next) {
191    var connect = require('connect');
192    var server = connect();
193    server.use(connect.static(paths.dist)).listen(process.env.PORT || 3002, next);
194  });
195  
196  
197

¶ trigger-reload

This task will watch for any files to change in the dist directory and trigger a livereload to happen.This should only be called as a subtask towatch.

 
202  
203  gulp.task('trigger-reload', function () {
204    var livereload = require('gulp-livereload');
205    var server = livereload();
206    gulp.watch(paths.dist + '/**').on('change', function (file) {
207      server.changed(file.path);
208    });
209  });
210  
211  
212  
213

¶ build-markup-with-livereload

This task will inject the necessary <script> tag into index.html in order to enable live reload via watch. This task should only need to be invoked as a dependency to the watch task.

 
219  
220  gulp.task('build-markup-with-livereload', function () {
221    var embedlr = require("gulp-embedlr");
222    gulp.src(paths.markup)
223      .pipe(embedlr())
224      .pipe(gulp.dest(paths.dist));
225  });
226  
227  
228

¶ help

List all available tasks. This directly uses the gulp-task-listing module to accomplish this. By default any tasks with a dash in the name is considered a "sub task" and will not be listed.

 
234  
235  gulp.task('help', require('gulp-task-listing'));
236  
237  
238  
239

¶ clean

Removes the dist directory and all build output.

 
243  
244  gulp.task('clean', function (cb) {
245    var rimraf = require('rimraf');
246    return rimraf('./dist', cb);
247  });
248  
249  
250

¶ beautify

This task will "beautify" the soruce JS files by formatting them according to the .jsbeautifyrc file. Note that this task is must be run manually (it is not part of the build task).

 
255  
256  gulp.task('beautify', function () {
257    var beautify = require('gulp-beautify');
258  
259    gulp.src(paths.scripts)
260      .pipe(beautify())
261      .pipe(gulp.dest(paths.scriptsRoot));
262  });
263  
264  
265

¶ defaut

The default task is watch

 
269  
270  gulp.task('default', ['watch']);
271
